column10: Public-facing site with analytics and tracking integrations.

column6: Structured method to categorise information assets (Public, Internal, Confidential etc.) ensuring proportional protection by sensitivity and operational impact.

column6: Protects stored data through cryptographic methods that prevent unauthorised disclosure or tampering on physical or virtual media.

column11: Key management complexity, performance impact, legacy storage compatibility.
column12: Data breach, loss of customer trust, compliance penalties.

column6: Control settings incorrectly implemented or inconsistent with baseline; recurring deviation after updates.
column7: Configuration drift detected; repeated deviations from baseline; rollback events increasing.
column8: Configuration drift reflects unmanaged change, indicating control execution is inconsistent or bypassed.
column9: Configuration baselines, segmentation policies, and continuous monitoring reduce setup drift and inconsistent enforcement.

column6: Delay in applying security updates or firmware; exposure window widened.
column7: Patch backlog > threshold; recurring “out-of-date” alerts; known CVEs unpatched.
column8: Patch backlog exposes systems to known vulnerabilities and signals weak update discipline.
column9: Integrated vulnerability and patch workflows minimise exposure from delayed updates.

column3: Safeguards information assets across storage, processing, and transmission environments. Focus areas: classification, encryption, retention, and confidentiality.
Manages authentication, authorisation, and trust boundaries across systems, users, and devices. Includes IAM, MFA, and privilege control.
Maintain governance arrangements for oversight of cyber, technology, and operational resilience risks.

column3: Define and maintain clear roles, responsibilities, and accountability for security and resilience activities.

column2: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management

column2: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
column4:
Ex1: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)
Ex2: Identify relevant external stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., privacy expectations of customers, business expectations of partnerships, compliance expectations of regulators, ethics expectations of society)
